resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <origination>
                     <persname>

Ungermann, Charles William, d. 1968.
</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>

Charles William Ungermann papers 
<unitdate>

1915-1967
</unitdate>
                  </unittitle>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>

1 linear foot and 2 oversize folders
</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <unitid>

88542 Aa 2; UAm; UAl
</unitid>
                  <langmaterial>The material is in <language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <abstract>

Detroit, Michigan, police officer. Scrapbooks containing material concerning the Detroit Police Department and Ungermann's career; also photographs.</abstract>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>
                        <subarea>Bentley Historical Library</subarea>, University of Michigan</corpname>
                     <extptr/>
                  </repository>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Charles William Ungermann papers 1915-1967
resource.abstract: Detroit, Michigan, police officer. Scrapbooks containing material concerning the Detroit Police Department and Ungermann's career; also photographs.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:57466590</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EYP</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>National Automotive History Collection (U.S.)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>WJR (Radio station : Detroit, Mich.)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Miscellaneous archive collection.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>1. Packard and Joy correspondence (1902-1903), letters from Henry Joy to James Packard during the time of the Packard Company's move from Warren, Ohio to Detroit, Mich.; 2. WJR Behind the Wheel (Jan-June 1946) contains reports of a 15 minute weekly radio program, written by George Cushing, on history of the automobile and automobile industry; 3. Automobile show commemorative postage stamp papers (1959-1960) press releases, memoranda and photographs concerning the 4-cent stamp, Wheels of Freedom, first sold at the 43rd National Automobile Show in Detroit on Oct. 15, 1960; 4. Rolls-Royce Owners' Club papers (1951-1956) correspondence, photographs and club literature collected by club member York R.F. Giddey; 5. G.M.C. experimental numbers book (1940-1983) bound record book of experimental numbers 201-710 of G.M.C. bus platforms; 6. Eugene W. Lewis papers (typescript), on the history of the automobile in the U.S. including histories of men of the industry, automobile marques and component parts; 7. Nolyn Bline's automotive notes (1928-1929) specifications, prices, retail sales and production rankings, copied from automotive trade journals such as Automobile Trade Journal, Automotive Topics and Motor Age for a number of American and European cars; 8. Perkins diesel engines, text and photographs concerning the adaptation and use of Perkins diesel engines in passenger cars, ca.1934-1960; 10. June 12, 1794 General Advertiser article "Curious Carriage" on a horseless carriage invented by a Mr. Blanchard of Philadelphia, and an Oct. 7, 1795 Columbian Sentinel article with an announcement for the last exhibition of the self-moving carriage. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Detroit Public Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Miscellaneous archive collection.
resource.abstract: 1. Packard and Joy correspondence (1902-1903), letters from Henry Joy to James Packard during the time of the Packard Company's move from Warren, Ohio to Detroit, Mich.; 2. WJR Behind the Wheel (Jan-June 1946) contains reports of a 15 minute weekly radio program, written by George Cushing, on history of the automobile and automobile industry; 3. Automobile show commemorative postage stamp papers (1959-1960) press releases, memoranda and photographs concerning the 4-cent stamp, Wheels of Freedom, first sold at the 43rd National Automobile Show in Detroit on Oct. 15, 1960; 4. Rolls-Royce Owners' Club papers (1951-1956) correspondence, photographs and club literature collected by club member York R.F. Giddey; 5. G.M.C. experimental numbers book (1940-1983) bound record book of experimental numbers 201-710 of G.M.C. bus platforms; 6. Eugene W. Lewis papers (typescript), on the history of the automobile in the U.S. including histories of men of the industry, automobile marques and component parts; 7. Nolyn Bline's automotive notes (1928-1929) specifications, prices, retail sales and production rankings, copied from automotive trade journals such as Automobile Trade Journal, Automotive Topics and Motor Age for a number of American and European cars; 8. Perkins diesel engines, text and photographs concerning the adaptation and use of Perkins diesel engines in passenger cars, ca.1934-1960; 10. June 12, 1794 General Advertiser article "Curious Carriage" on a horseless carriage invented by a Mr. Blanchard of Philadelphia, and an Oct. 7, 1795 Columbian Sentinel article with an announcement for the last exhibition of the self-moving carriage.
resource.displayEntry: National Automotive History Collection (U.S.). Miscellaneous archive collection.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <origination>
                     <persname>

Cushing, George William, 1888-1968.
</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>

George William Cushing papers and sound recordings 
<unitdate>

1942-1955
</unitdate>
                  </unittitle>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>

1.3 linear feet and ca. 230 audiotapes (in 9 boxes)
</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <unitid>

851077 Aa 2
</unitid>
                  <langmaterial>The material is in <language>English</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <abstract>

News editor and vice president of Detroit, Michigan, radio station, WJR, moderator of radio program, "In Our Opinion". Correspondence, radio transcripts, scrapbooks, broadcast discs, and audio-tapes of discs; include material concerning career of Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, the senatorial campaign of 1942 between Prentiss Brown and Homer Ferguson, and radio broadcasting in general.</abstract>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>
                        <subarea>Bentley Historical Library</subarea>, University of Michigan</corpname>
                     <extptr/>
                  </repository>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: George William Cushing papers and sound recordings 1942-1955
resource.abstract: News editor and vice president of Detroit, Michigan, radio station, WJR, moderator of radio program, "In Our Opinion". Correspondence, radio transcripts, scrapbooks, broadcast discs, and audio-tapes of discs; include material concerning career of Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, the senatorial campaign of 1942 between Prentiss Brown and Homer Ferguson, and radio broadcasting in general.
resource.extent: 1.3 linear feet and ca. 230 audiotapes (in 9 boxes)
resource.displayEntry: George William Cushing papers and sound recordings, 1942-1955

                     </role>

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Emrich, Richard S. M. (Richard Stanley Merrill), 1910-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Ferguson, Homer, 1889-1982.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Heyerdahl, Thor.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Marshall, S. L. A. (Samuel Lyman Atwood), 1900-1977.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Murrow, Edward R.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Pollock, James Kerr, 1898-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Romney, George W., 1907-1995.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Sigler, Kim, b. 1894.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Thomas, Lowell, 1892-1981.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Vandenberg, Arthur H. (Arthur Hendrick), 1884-1951.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>George Cushing sound recordings, 1942-1955.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Sound recording copies of original and transmission discs of a selection of the "In Our Opinion" radio program. Among guests were Senators Arthur Vandenberg and Homer Ferguson, automobile executive (later governor) George Romney, Congressman George Dondero, military historian General S.L.A. Marshall, political science Professor James K. Pollock, Governor Kim Sigler, Lowell Thomas, Thor Heyerdahl, Edward R. Murrow, and Episcopal Bishop Richard S. Emrich, among many others. Topics ranged from state and national politics, the impact of the war, foreign affairs, post-war re-conversion of the economy, and issues specific to Detroit and Michigan. One of the tapes is of the debate between Homer Ferguson and Prentiss Brown, candidates for the U.S. Senate in 1942. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>University of Michigan</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: George Cushing sound recordings, 1942-1955.
resource.abstract: Sound recording copies of original and transmission discs of a selection of the "In Our Opinion" radio program. Among guests were Senators Arthur Vandenberg and Homer Ferguson, automobile executive (later governor) George Romney, Congressman George Dondero, military historian General S.L.A. Marshall, political science Professor James K. Pollock, Governor Kim Sigler, Lowell Thomas, Thor Heyerdahl, Edward R. Murrow, and Episcopal Bishop Richard S. Emrich, among many others. Topics ranged from state and national politics, the impact of the war, foreign affairs, post-war re-conversion of the economy, and issues specific to Detroit and Michigan. One of the tapes is of the debate between Homer Ferguson and Prentiss Brown, candidates for the U.S. Senate in 1942.
resource.extent: ca. 230 sound tape reels : 7¹/₂ ips ; 7 in.
resource.displayEntry: Cushing, George William, 1888-1968. George Cushing sound recordings, 1942-1955.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <origination>
                     <famname>Rowe Family</famname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Rowe Family Papers [microform]
<unitdate>1840-1990</unitdate>
                     <unitdate>1840s-1940s</unitdate>
                  </unittitle>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>0.7 linear feet (on 2 rolls of microfilm) and 0.3 linear feet (in 1 box)</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <abstract>Residents of Highland Township, Oakland County, Michigan. Civil War reminiscences and other papers of James D. Rowe, soldier in the 1st Michigan Cavalry; Civil War letters of Spencer D. Lee, related family member, also in the 1st Michigan Cavalry; business records of Grant and Carrie Jackson Rowe, publishers of the Milford Times; sermons of Samuel Simpson Marquis as transcribed by Mrs. G. S. Rowe; collected materials largely concerning Milford and Highland Township history; and miscellaneous photographs and Civil War print.</abstract>
                  <unitid>852173 mf334, mf335</unitid>
                  <langmaterial>The materials are in <language>English.</language>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>
                        <subarea>Bentley Historical Library</subarea> University of Michigan</corpname>
                     <extptr/>
                  </repository>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Rowe Family Papers [microform] 1840-1990 1840s-1940s
resource.abstract: Residents of Highland Township, Oakland County, Michigan. Civil War reminiscences and other papers of James D. Rowe, soldier in the 1st Michigan Cavalry; Civil War letters of Spencer D. Lee, related family member, also in the 1st Michigan Cavalry; business records of Grant and Carrie Jackson Rowe, publishers of the Milford Times; sermons of Samuel Simpson Marquis as transcribed by Mrs. G. S. Rowe; collected materials largely concerning Milford and Highland Township history; and miscellaneous photographs and Civil War print.
resource.extent: 0.7 linear feet (on 2 rolls of microfilm) and 0.3 linear feet (in 1 box)
